questions.text: A preterm newborn with intrauterine growth restriction presents at birth with jaundice, hepatosplenomegaly, microcephaly, diffuse petechiae, and a brain CT scan revealing periventricular calcifications. What is the most appropriate method to diagnose the underlying cause of this condition?
questions.solution:
The newborn's clinical presentation of growth restriction, hepatosplenomegaly, microcephaly, petechiae, and periventricular calcifications on imaging is highly indicative of congenital cytomegalovirus (CMV) infection. The best method for diagnosing congenital CMV is urine examination.

Cytomegalovirus (CMV):

  • Transmission Routes:
    • CMV is transmitted via body fluids like saliva, urine, blood, vaginal secretions, and breast milk.
  • Maternal-Fetal Transmission:
    • 30% of fetuses are affected when a mother has a primary CMV infection during pregnancy.
  • Clinical Features:
    • Asymptomatic in 90% of newborns.
    • Symptomatic in 10%, with the following common signs:
      • Jaundice (direct bilirubin > 2 mg/dL)
      • Petechiae and purpura (may present with "blueberry muffin" appearance)
      • Hepatosplenomegaly
      • Microcephaly
      • Chorioretinitis
      • Intrauterine growth restriction
      • Hearing loss is the most frequent long-term complication and may not be evident at birth.
  • Diagnostic Approach:
    • Timing is crucial: Diagnosis must be confirmed within the first 2 to 3 weeks of life to be considered congenital.
    • Elevated ALT, direct hyperbilirubinemia, thrombocytopenia
    • Preferred Tests:
      • PCR (Polymerase Chain Reaction): High sensitivity for detecting CMV DNA; used to quantify viral load.
      • Viral culture: Can be paired with immunofluorescence to detect CMV proteins.
    • Best Specimens:
      • Urine and saliva are the most reliable for detection.
      • Urine testing is preferred due to higher viral load and detection sensitivity.
      • Blood may be used but is generally less sensitive.
    • Neuroimaging: Periventricular calcifications are a hallmark
  • Management:
    • No universally standardized treatment protocol; individualized based on symptom severity.
    • Ganciclovir IV, 6 weeks is often used in severe or symptomatic cases to potentially reduce long-term complications.
    • Valganciclovir as an alternative to ganciclovir in milder cases, per recent guidelines.
  • Follow-up:
    • Routine hearing assessments
    • Developmental evaluations
    • Regular vision screening

questions.text: A newborn girl presents with ambiguous genitalia, clitoromegaly, and labial fusion. She is found to have normal internal female organs. Laboratory tests reveal hyponatremia, hyperkalemia, and elevated 17-hydroxyprogesterone. What is the most likely underlying condition?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis is female pseudohermaphroditism due to 21-hydroxylase deficiency, the most common form of congenital adrenal hyperplasia. Excess prenatal androgens virilize 46,XX fetuses, while cortisol and aldosterone deficiency lead to electrolyte abnormalities.

Congenital Adrenal Hyperplasia (CAH):

  • Predominantly due to 21-hydroxylase deficiency.
  • Hormonal Variants:
    • Salt-wasting form: Both cortisol and aldosterone are deficient.
    • Simple virilizing form: Aldosterone is preserved; excess androgens are produced.
    • Nonclassic form: Mild androgen excess; symptoms may be absent or minimal.
  • Clinical Presentation:
    • Aldosterone and Cortisol Deficiency (in salt-wasting form):
      • Seen in about 70% of CAH patients.
      • Symptoms include weight loss, vomiting, dehydration, low blood pressure, low blood sugar, hyponatremia, and hyperkalemia.
    • Effects of Androgen Excess in Utero:
      • In 46,XX individuals (genetic females), elevated prenatal androgens cause genital virilization, leading to:
        • Enlarged clitoris (clitoromegaly)
        • Fusion of labia
        • Formation of a common urogenital sinus
      • However, internal reproductive organs (uterus and ovaries) are normal since there is no antimüllerian hormone being produced.
      • In 46,XY infants (genetic males), the genitalia appear typical at birth, often delaying diagnosis until symptoms of adrenal insufficiency appear.
    • Postnatal Androgen Excess:
      • Males: May present with enlarged phallus, small prepubertal testes, or develop testicular adrenal rest tumors.
      • Females: Can develop progressive clitoromegaly, primary amenorrhea, and lack of secondary sexual characteristics without treatment.
  • Laboratory Findings:
    • Salt-wasting form: Electrolyte imbalances including low sodium, high potassium, metabolic acidosis, and hypoglycemia.
    • Hormonal profile shows increased 17-hydroxyprogesterone, androstenedione, and testosterone (especially in females).
    • ACTH stimulation test: A significant rise in 17-hydroxyprogesterone confirms CAH diagnosis.
  • Management:
    • Medical Therapy:
      • Glucocorticoids: Replace cortisol and suppress excess androgen production.
      • Mineralocorticoids: Required in salt-wasting cases to correct aldosterone deficiency.
    • Surgical Interventions:
      • Clitoral reduction surgery may be considered in cases of severe clitoromegaly.
      • Vaginoplasty and correction of urogenital sinus anomalies may also be needed.

Explanation of other options:

Male pseudohermaphroditism (Option A): Typically results from 17α-hydroxylase deficiency, not 21-hydroxylase deficiency. These individuals have 46,XY karyotype but incomplete virilization.

True hermaphroditism (Option C): Characterized by the presence of both ovarian and testicular tissue, which is not a feature of CAH.

46, XY intersex(Option D): Includes conditions with ambiguous genitalia in 46, XY individuals due to enzyme defects or androgen insensitivity, but differs from 21-hydroxylase deficiency CAH, which usually affects 46, XX individuals.

questions.text: Which disorder is most consistent with the inheritance pattern shown in the pedigree?
questions.solution: The pedigree shows a classic X-linked recessive inheritance pattern, primarily affecting males and passed through unaffected carrier females, without father-to-son transmission. Among the listed options, color blindness best fits this inheritance mode.

questions.text: A newborn presents with persistent unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia lasting beyond 3 weeks of age. Investigations show normal liver enzymes, normal PT/INR, and normal albumin levels. No signs of hemolysis are noted on peripheral smear. Following phenobarbital therapy, a notable decline in bilirubin levels is observed within a week. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution: This clinical scenario is indicative of a nonhemolytic unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia in a neonate with preserved liver function. The significant improvement after phenobarbital administration is characteristic of Crigler-Najjar syndrome type 2, making it the most probable diagnosis.

questions.text: A 9-year-old boy presents with joint swelling in both knees and a purplish, raised rash on his lower legs as shown below that does not fade on pressure. Laboratory tests reveal hematuria and mild proteinuria. His platelet count is normal. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This presentation is consistent with Henoch-Schönlein purpura (HSP), an IgA-mediated vasculitis affecting small vessels, most often seen in children between 3-8 years of age.

Key Clinical Features:
  • Palpable purpura: Non-blanching rashes over the lower limbs are a hallmark feature.
  • Arthritis and arthralgia: Joint involvement is common, especially in the knees and ankles, and may present with pain, swelling, or stiffness.
  • Renal signs: Hematuria and mild proteinuria indicate kidney involvement, resembling IgA nephropathy.
  • Normal platelet levels: Helps distinguish HSP from thrombocytopenic conditions like ITP.

HSP often occurs following a recent upper respiratory infection. It is caused by deposition of IgA immune complexes in the dermal capillaries and kidney mesangium.

Explanation of other options:

Systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) (Option A): Less common at this young age; typically presents with malar rash, systemic features, and positive autoimmune antibodies (e.g., ANA, anti-dsDNA).

Immune thrombocytopenic purpura (ITP) (Option C): Presents with thrombocytopenia leading to petechiae/purpura, but without arthritis or renal signs.

Polyarteritis nodosa (PAN) (Option D): Affects medium-sized arteries, usually with systemic manifestations like fever, hypertension, weight loss, and abdominal pain, without IgA deposits or typical purpura.

questions.text: A newborn is evaluated 5 minutes after birth. The baby is cyanotic, has irregular and gasping respiration, a heart rate of 60 beats per minute, minimal response to stimulation, and exhibits some flexion of limbs. What is the most accurate Apgar score?
questions.solution:
Apgar score is calculated as follows:

  • Appearance (skin color): Baby is completely cyanosed - Score 0.
  • Pulse (heart rate): Heart rate is 60 beats per minute (below 100) - Score 1.
  • Grimace (reflex irritability): Minimal response to stimulation - Score 1.
  • Activity (muscle tone): Baby shows some flexion of extremities - Score 1.
  • Respiratory effort: Breathing is irregular and gasping - Score 1.

Adding all the components: 0 (appearance) + 1 (pulse) + 1 (grimace) + 1 (activity) + 1 (respiration) = Apgar score of 4.

Apgar Scoring System:

  • Assessed at 1 and 5 minutes post-delivery to evaluate the newborn's cardiopulmonary status and adaptation to the postnatal environment.
  • If the 5-minute score is less than 7, it is repeated every 5 minutes up to 20 minutes.
  • A score between 0-3 at 5 minutes is associated with a higher risk of mortality.
  • The Apgar score assesses a newborn's condition at 1 and 5 minutes post-delivery.
    • Scores of 0-3 at 5 minutes indicate a need for urgent resuscitation and are associated with higher risk of morbidity.
    • Scores of 4-6 suggest the need for supportive measures.

questions.text: A laborer brings his second child to the outpatient clinic due to a noticeably bloated abdomen and dull facial expression. The child has primarily been fed rice water. Lab tests reveal low serum albumin and total protein levels. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The child's swollen abdomen, dull facial expression, and low serum protein and albumin, along with a diet mainly of rice water, are classic features of Kwashiorkor, a form of protein-energy malnutrition. It typically affects children aged 1 to 3 years who consume enough calories but insufficient protein.

Explanation of other options:

Indian childhood cirrhosis (Option C): Affects the liver, causing hepatomegaly and fibrosis but not associated with generalized edema or dull facial features.

Kawasaki disease (Option D): Presents with high fever, conjunctivitis, rash, and extremity changes, not with malnutrition or protein deficiency signs.

Reference: Wellcome Classification, Page 3

questions.text: A full-term newborn presents with visible bowel loops herniating through a defect in the anterior abdominal wall, located just to the right of the umbilical cord insertion. The intestines are uncovered and appear inflamed. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Gastroschisis is a congenital condition characterized by an abdominal wall defect usually found to the right of the umbilicus, where intestines protrude freely without a protective covering. The exposed loops are directly in contact with amniotic fluid.



Explanation of other options:

Umbilical hernia (Option B): Occurs through the umbilical ring; abdominal contents bulge out but remain within skin and peritoneum. No right-sided protrusion.


Ectopia vesicae (Option D): A developmental anomaly where the bladder lies exposed on the surface of the lower abdominal wall, unrelated to bowel herniation.


Reference:

  1. https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK519010/#

questions.text: A 4-year-old male presents with progressive muscle weakness, difficulty rising from the floor, and trouble climbing stairs. Muscle biopsy reveals small muscle fibers and a complete absence of dystrophin protein. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• Duchenne muscular dystrophy (DMD) is an X-linked recessive neuromuscular disorder that arises due to mutations in the DMD gene, leading to loss of dystrophin, a key structural protein in muscle fibers.
  • Affected boys commonly show signs in early childhood such as difficulty climbing stairs, frequent falls, and Gower's sign (using hands to rise from the floor).
  • Diagnostic confirmation is achieved through muscle biopsy, which shows degeneration of muscle fibers and complete absence of dystrophin.

Explanation of other options:

Myotonic dystrophy (Option C): An unrelated disorder marked by delayed muscle relaxation (myotonia), cataracts, and cardiac issues. It is caused by mutations in the DMPK or CNBP genes. Dystrophin is not affected.

Limb-girdle muscular dystrophy (Option D): A heterogeneous group of disorders affecting shoulder and pelvic girdle muscles. These are not dystrophinopathies; dystrophin staining remains intact on biopsy.

questions.text: A 4-week-old male infant is brought in with a history of repeated projectile, non-bilious vomiting after feeding. On examination, a firm, olive-shaped mass is palpated in the epigastric region, and visible gastric peristalsis is observed moving from left to right. Laboratory investigations are most likely to show which of the following metabolic abnormalities?
questions.solution:
• The clinical presentation of projectile non-bilious vomiting in a young infant with a palpable "olive" in the epigastrium strongly suggests infantile hypertrophic pyloric stenosis (IHPS).
  • Vomiting in this condition results in significant loss of gastric hydrochloric acid, depleting both hydrogen and chloride ions, which contributes to the development of metabolic alkalosis. The continued loss of gastric contents also reduces potassium levels, leading to hypokalemia alongside hypochloremic alkalosis.

Congenital hypertrophic pyloric stenosis (CHPS):

  • Age group: Commonly presents between 3-6 weeks
  • Gender: More frequent in male infants
  • Symptoms: Forceful, projectile nonbilious vomiting
  • Signs:
    • Palpable "olive-shaped" mass in the epigastric region
    • Visible left-to-right gastric peristalsis
    • Dehydration and weight loss
    • Hypochloremic hypokalemic metabolic alkalosis with paradoxical aciduria
  • Diagnostic Imaging:
    • Ultrasound (Preferred):
    • Muscle thickness > 4 mm
    • Channel length > 16 mm
    • Elongated and thickened pyloric canal
  • Upper GI Contrast Study (if needed):
    • String sign: Thin streak of contrast through narrowed pylorus
    • Delayed gastric emptying, no duodenal dilation

questions.text: A 6-year-old girl presents with bowing of the legs and widening of the wrists, noted since age 2, without improvement despite multiple courses of vitamin D therapy. Laboratory findings reveal calcium 9.5 mg/dL, phosphate 1.6 mg/dL, and alkaline phosphatase 814 IU/L. Her PTH, renal function, electrolytes, and arterial blood gas are within normal limits. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This child's skeletal deformities and poor response to vitamin D supplementation, along with normal calcium and low phosphate levels, point toward hypophosphatemic rickets. This condition is commonly caused by a defect in renal phosphate reabsorption, leading to persistent hypophosphatemia and impaired bone mineralization.

Hypophosphatemic rickets:

  • Inheritance: Most commonly X-linked dominant (PHEX gene mutation).
  • Clinical Features: Bowing of legs, skull shape anomalies, dental abnormalities.
  • Investigations:
    • Calcium: Normal
    • Phosphate: Decreased
    • ALP: Elevated
    • PTH: Normal
    • Vitamin D: Inappropriately low or normal
    • Urine phosphate: Increased
  • Treatment: Oral phosphate supplements and vitamin D3.

Explanation of other options:

Vitamin D dependent rickets (Option A): Typically associated with high PTH and may have low calcium. This child's PTH is normal and calcium is normal, making this diagnosis unlikely.

Hypoparathyroidism (Option B): Characterized by low calcium and high phosphate due to deficient PTH. Normal calcium and low phosphate here exclude hypoparathyroidism.

Chronic renal failure (Option C): Often leads to phosphate retention, elevated creatinine, and metabolic disturbances. Normal renal function and electrolytes rule this out.

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy presents with seizures. He had a febrile illness with a rash at the age of 1 year, which resolved spontaneously. Which of the following investigations would be most useful in establishing the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of seizures in a school-aged child, coupled with a history of a self-limited febrile exanthem in infancy, raises suspicion for Subacute Sclerosing Panencephalitis (SSPE), a progressive and fatal delayed complication of a prior measles infection. Detection of elevated measles-specific IgG antibodies in cerebrospinal fluid is a cornerstone of diagnosis, reflecting prior infection and ongoing CNS involvement.

Subacute Sclerosing Panencephalitis

  • Definition: A fatal, slowly progressive neurological disorder caused by persistent measles virus in the brain, manifesting years after the initial infection. Also called Dawson disease or slow-virus encephalitis.
  • Onset: Usually emerges 7-13 years following measles infection.
  • Symptoms: Gradual development of behavioral issues, cognitive decline, myoclonic jerks, and progressive neurological impairment.
  • EEG Findings: Periodic high-voltage discharges and burst-suppression complexes.
  • Neuroimaging: MRI may show generalized brain atrophy and white matter changes but is not diagnostic.
  • Diagnosis: Based on history, clinical course, characteristic EEG, and elevated measles-specific IgG levels in the CSF.

Explanation of other options:

MRI mesial temporal lobe sclerosis (Option B): This MRI finding is associated with temporal lobe epilepsy and involves structural changes in the mesial temporal region (especially the hippocampus). It does not confirm SSPE.

lgM measles in CSF (Option C): IgM antibodies indicate a recent measles infection. Since SSPE manifests years after the initial episode, IgM is typically absent and not useful for diagnosis.

Anti-C1q antibodies in the CSF (Option D): These are not associated with measles or subacute sclerosing panencephalitis (SSPE). They are primarily linked to autoimmune disorders, particularly systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE), especially in cases with lupus nephritis.

choices.text: Severe malnutrition - refer to nutrition rehabilitation centre
Moderate malnutrition - educate the mother on feeding practices

questions.text: A 16-month-old boy weighs 8 kg. Based on the WHO weight-for-age growth chart provided below, what would be the most appropriate course of action?
questions.solution:
• At 16 months of age, a weight of 8 kg places this child between -2 SD and -3 SD from the mean on the WHO weight-for-age reference chart. This range classifies him as moderately underweight, indicating moderate malnutrition.
  • While his nutritional status is compromised, it does not yet meet the criteria for severe malnutrition, and therefore, immediate referral to a nutrition rehabilitation center is not warranted.
  • Instead, the focus should be on educating the mother or caregiver on proper feeding practices and providing guidance on improving the child's nutritional intake.
  • This may involve promoting a balanced diet, ensuring adequate calorie and nutrient intake, and addressing any feeding difficulties or challenges.

WHO Growth Charts:

  • Developed through the WHO Multicentre Growth Reference Study (MGRS) conducted in multiple countries (India, Brazil, Ghana, Norway, Oman, and the USA).
  • Charts are used to assess growth parameters in children under 5.
  • The chart uses percentile or Z-score curves to monitor trends in weight, height/length, and head circumference.
  • Z-score Classification for Weight-for-Age:
    • Normal range: Between -2 SD and +2 SD
    • Mild underweight: Between -2 SD and -1 SD
    • Moderate underweight: Between -3 SD and -2 SD
    • Severe underweight: Below -3 SD

questions.text: A 7-year-old boy undergoing chemotherapy presents with abdominal pain, vomiting, reduced urine output, and swelling around the eyes. Laboratory evaluation reveals elevated uric acid, high serum creatinine, and hyperkalemia. What is the next best step in management?
questions.solution:
The presentation of abdominal pain, vomiting, oliguria, and facial puffiness in a child receiving chemotherapy, along with laboratory abnormalities such as elevated uric acid, increased serum creatinine, and high potassium levels, is highly indicative of tumor lysis syndrome (TLS). The next best step is to initiate intravenous hydration.

Tumor Lysis Syndrome (TLS):

  • Refers to a condition marked by widespread breakdown of tumor cells, resulting in various metabolic disturbances.
  • These include elevated potassium and phosphate levels, reduced calcium, and increased uric acid, all of which can contribute to damage of vital organs.
  • This syndrome is predominantly seen in individuals diagnosed with hematological cancers.
  • Clinical Presentation:
    • Gastrointestinal manifestations: Includes abdominal pain and bloating.
    • Urinary complaints: May present with pain during urination, decreased urine output (oliguria), pain in the flanks, and blood in the urine (hematuria).
    • Low calcium-related symptoms: These may include:
      • Loss of appetite
      • Nausea and vomiting
      • Muscle stiffness or spasms
      • Convulsions
      • Involuntary muscle contractions (tetany)
      • Changes in consciousness or cognition
  • Timing and Associated Cancers:
    • Usually arises between 12 and 48 hours after chemotherapy begins, but in some high-tumor-burden cancers such as Burkitt lymphoma, lymphoblastic lymphoma, or leukemias with very high white cell counts, it may also occur spontaneously.
  • Evaluation Prior to Therapy:
    • Before starting treatment, it is essential to assess:
      • Serum levels of uric acid, electrolytes, calcium, phosphate, and creatinine
      • Ensure the patient is well-hydrated
  • Preventive Measures:
    • Allopurinol, a xanthine oxidase inhibitor, is used to stop the buildup of uric acid. (Option C)
    • Rasburicase, which enzymatically degrades uric acid, is administered to individuals at high risk or in whom TLS has already developed. (Option D)

Explanation of other options:

Probenecid (Option B): Although it promotes uric acid excretion, it's not recommended in TLS, as it can raise urinary uric acid levels, increasing the risk of urate nephropathy and stone formation.

Reference:

  1. https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK518985/

questions.text: A full-term 8-day-old neonate is found to have a thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH) level exceeding 100 mIU/L on newborn screening. Which of the following would be the most appropriate next diagnostic step?
questions.solution:
In a newborn with markedly elevated TSH, congenital hypothyroidism is suspected. The next best investigation is a thyroid scan using technetium-99m pertechnetate to assess the presence, location, and functional status of thyroid tissue. This helps differentiate between thyroid dysgenesis (agenesis, ectopia), and dyshormonogenesis.

Congenital hypothyroidism:

  • Is the most common preventable cause of mental retardation, which results from a deficient production of thyroid hormone.
  • More common among girls
  • The most common cause of congenital hypothyroidism is thyroid dysgenesis.
  • Etiology of congenital hypothyroidism:
  1. Primary hypothyroidism:
    • Thyroid dysgenesis
    • Thyroid dyshormonogenesis
    • Iodine deficiency
    • Transport defects from MCT8 gene mutations
    • Transplacental passage of maternal thyrotropin receptor-blocking antibodies (TRBAb)
    • Antithyroid drugs taken by the mother
  2. Central (hypopituitary) hypothyroidism:
    • Prolonged neonatal jaundice
    • Treatment-resistant constipation
    • Wide anterior/posterior fontanelles
    • Macroglossia
    • Developmental delays
    • Poor growth
    • Delayed teeth eruption
    • Hypotonia, hypothermia
    • Macrocytic anemia that does not respond to treatment.
  • Diagnosis:
    • Primary hypothyroidism is characterized by very low T4 and TSH levels exceeding 100 mIU/L.
    • Central hypothyroidism presents with low T3, T4, and TSH.
    • Radionuclide scan (Technetium-99m or Iodine-123) or thyroid ultrasound is essential to determine the gland's location, size, and structure, helping identify dysgenesis, dyshormonogenesis, or transient forms.
  • Management:
    • Oral levothyroxine is the treatment of choice.
    • Dose adjustments are age-dependent:
      • Neonates: 10-15 mcg/kg/day
      • Children: 2-4 mcg/kg/day

Explanation of other options:

Urine iodine excretion (Option A): Best used in public health settings to assess population-level iodine nutrition, not for individual diagnosis.

Serum thyroid receptor antibody (Option B): Primarily relevant if maternal autoimmune thyroid disease is suspected; useful in cases of transient neonatal hypothyroidism.

Perchlorate secretion test (Option D): Identifies defects in iodine organification (e.g., TPO deficiency), but is not a first-line investigation for congenital hypothyroidism.

Reference:

https://www.msdmanuals.com/professional/pediatrics/endocrine-disorders-in-children/hypothyroidism-in-infants-and-children#

questions.text: A 10-month-old infant presents with sudden flexion jerks of the limbs and has shown a loss of previously attained developmental milestones. On EEG, a chaotic pattern of high-voltage slow waves with multifocal waves and spikes is observed. What is the most appropriate first-line treatment?
questions.solution:
The child's presentation of flexor spasms, developmental regression, and the presence of hypsarrhythmia on EEG is indicative of West syndrome, also known as infantile spasms. The preferred initial therapy is ACTH (Adrenocorticotropic hormone).

West Syndrome:

  • Typical Age of Onset: Usually occurs between 2 to 12 months of age.
  • Genetics:ARX gene mutations are implicated, especially in male infants, linked to ambiguous genitalia and cortical migration abnormalities.
  • Clinical Signs:
    • Epileptic Spasms: Sudden, brief muscle contractions that happen in clusters, often during transitions from sleep.
    • Developmental Regression: Loss of previously acquired skills.
    • Hypsarrhythmia on EEG: Characterized by high-amplitude, disorganized background activity with multifocal spikes and waves.
  • Treatment Approach:
    • ACTH Therapy: First-line treatment.
      • Dosage: 150 units/m²/day (administered as 75 units/mm² twice daily) for 2 weeks, followed by a taper.
      • Monitoring: EEG at weeks 1, 2, and 4 to monitor effectiveness.
    • Alternative & Adjunct Treatments:
      • Oral Prednisolone: A more economical but less potent alternative to ACTH.
      • Vigabatrin: Especially useful if West syndrome is associated with tuberous sclerosis complex (TSC); risk of retinal toxicity is a concern.
      • Ketogenic Diet: Considered if initial therapies fail.

Explanation of other options:

Phenytoin (Option A): Mainly used for focal seizures and status epilepticus; it does not address infantile spasms or EEG abnormalities like hypsarrhythmia.

Levetiracetam (Option C): Has no proven efficacy for infantile spasms.

Phenobarbitone (Option D): Although it's a common choice in neonatal seizures, it is less effective for infantile spasms compared to ACTH.

questions.text: A child has been experiencing frequent loose stools for the past 4 days. On examination, he appears drowsy, is unable to drink or feed, and his skin shows a very slow return to normal after pinching. Based on the Integrated Management of Neonatal and Childhood Illness (IMNCI) guidelines, how should this child's condition be classified?
questions.solution:
According to the IMNCI guidelines, the presence of drowsiness, inability to feed, and very slow skin pinch recoil in a child with frequent diarrhea strongly indicates severe dehydration.

Evaluation of Dehydration in Pediatric Patients:

  • General Signs: Observe dryness of the mouth, sunken fontanelle in infants, and signs of irritability or restlessness.
  • Skin Turgor Test: Gently pinch the skin and note how quickly it returns; slower return indicates greater dehydration.
  • Capillary Refill: Press on the nail bed or sternum and release. A delay in color return (>2 seconds) can suggest dehydration.
  • Urine Output: Reduced frequency or fewer wet diapers suggest fluid loss.
  • Vital Signs: Tachycardia and hypotension may be present in advanced cases.
  • Consciousness Level: Changes in alertness, such as drowsiness or lethargy, can indicate moderate to severe dehydration.

choices.text: Manage ABC, NS 20 mL/kg and start insulin after 1 hour
Manage ABC, NS 20 mL/kg along with insulin 0.1 IU/kg/hr
Manage ABC, NS 10 mL/kg along with insulin 0.1 IU/kg/hr
Manage ABC, NS 10 mL/kg and start insulin after 1 hour

questions.text: A 10-year-old child weighing 30 kg is brought in with a 2-day history of diarrhea. On assessment, the child appears severely dehydrated. Laboratory findings include a random blood sugar of 550 mg/dL, blood pH of 7.01, serum sodium of 158 mEq/L, and urine positive for glucose (3+). What is the initial management as per ISPAD guidelines?
questions.solution:
The clinical and laboratory profile, including profound dehydration, hyperglycemia (RBS 550 mg/dL), acidemia (pH 7.01), and significant glycosuria, suggests a diagnosis of diabetic ketoacidosis (DKA). Per ISPAD recommendations, the child should first receive resuscitative care with normal saline at 20 mL/kg, while insulin infusion 0.1 IU/kg/hr should be initiated only after one hour of fluid therapy.

Diabetic ketoacidosis (DKA):

  • DKA is a common acute complication observed in children and adolescents with both type 1 and type 2 diabetes mellitus.
  • Clinical Signs:
    • Dehydration
    • Tachycardia and tachypnea.
    • Kussmaul breathing: Characterized by deep, labored respiration with a fruity or acetone-like smell on the breath.
    • Gastrointestinal issues: Nausea, vomiting, and abdominal pain.
    • Neurological involvement: Drowsiness, disorientation, or gradual decline in consciousness.
  • Biochemical Parameters for Diagnosis:
    • Hyperglycemia: Blood glucose >11 mmol/L or ≥200 mg/dL.
    • Acidosis: Venous: pH <7.3 and/or bicarbonate <15 mmol/L.
    • Ketone Accumulation:
      • In blood (Ketonemia): β-hydroxybutyrate concentration ≥3 mmol/L.
      • In urine (Ketonuria): Detected as moderate to large ketone levels.
  • Management:

Reference:

  1. Pediatric Diabetic Ketoacidosis - StatPearls - NCBI Bookshelf
  2. https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC4413392/

choices.text: Increase in length of 25 centimetres in the first year
Weight gain of 300 grams per month till 1 year
Anterior fontanelle closure by 6 months of age
Weight under the 75th percentile and height under the 25th percentile

questions.text: Which of the following most reliably indicates appropriate physical growth in an infant born with a weight of 2.8 kg?
questions.solution:
A 25 cm increase in length during the first year is considered the most reliable marker of appropriate growth in infancy.

Normal Growth Milestones:

  • At birth: Length is approximately 50 cm.
  • At 1 year: Expected to reach 75 cm.
  • At 2 years: Increases by 10-15 cm to reach about 85-90 cm.
  • From age 2 to 12: Linear growth continues at around 6 cm/year.

Height Landmarks:

  • Doubles by around 4 years.
  • Triples by 12 years.
  • At 2 years, a child achieves about 50% of adult height (80-85 cm).

Growth Chart Formulas - Weech's Rule:

  • <1 year: (Age in months + 9) ÷ 2
  • 1-6 years: (2 × age in years) + 8
  • 7-12 years: (7 × age in years - 5) ÷ 2

Explanation of other options:

Weight gain of 300 grams per month till 1 year (Option B): Weight gain of 300g/month is below the typical rate, especially in early months where 20-40g/day is expected, and gain reaches ~400g/month after 4 months.

Anterior fontanelle closure by 6 months of age (Option C): The anterior fontanelle typically closes between 9-18 months, not by 6 months, and varies significantly, hence not a consistent growth marker.

Weight under the 75th percentile and height under the 25th percentile (Option D): While percentiles help compare with population norms, being below the 75th percentile for weight and 25th percentile for height does not inherently imply healthy or adequate growth.

Reference:

  1. https://www.pedgen.org.in/growth.php
  2. https://journals.lww.com/njcp/fulltext/2020/23090/comparison_of_age_based_weight_estimation_with.8.aspx

questions.text: A 3-week-old infant presents with a sore throat and episodes of paroxysmal coughing followed by apnea. Laboratory results show a total leukocyte count exceeding 50,000 cells/μL. Which medication should be prescribed for this patient?
questions.solution:
The combination of paroxysmal coughing, apnea, and marked leukocytosis in a young infant is characteristic of pertussis (whooping cough). Azithromycin is the recommended first-line antibiotic for pertussis across all age groups.

Pertussis:

  • Causative Organism: Bordetella pertussis or Bordetella parapertussis.
  • Clinical Stages:
    • Catarrhal phase (1-2 weeks): Mild respiratory symptoms.
    • Paroxysmal phase (2-6 weeks): Repetitive coughing fits, "whoop" sound, post-tussive vomiting.
    • Convalescent phase (1-4 weeks): Gradual recovery.
  • Complications: Apnea, pneumonia, otitis media, seizures, pulmonary hypertension, cardiogenic shock, and malnutrition.
  • Diagnosis: Primarily clinical; supported by nasopharyngeal swab culture, PCR, or serology.
  • Management:
    • First-line Treatment: Azithromycin is the preferred antibiotic for pertussis in all age groups.
    • Antibiotics are most effective during the catarrhal phase.
    • Isolation for at least 5 days after initiation of antibiotics is recommended to reduce transmission.
  • Prevention:
    • DTaP vaccine for children <7 years.
    • Tdap booster for older children, adults, and pregnant women (preferably between 27-36 weeks gestation).

Explanation of other options:

Amoxicillin (Option B): Ineffective against Bordetella pertussis and not recommended for pertussis.

Cotrimoxazole (Option C): Reserved for macrolide intolerance; contraindicated in infants <2 months due to kernicterus risk.

Clarithromycin (Option D): Avoided in infants <1 month due to risk of infantile hypertrophic pyloric stenosis (IHPS).

Reference:

  1. https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK519008/

questions.text: A child is presented with breathing difficulty and biphasic stridor. The provided radiographic image is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The presence of respiratory distress combined with biphasic stridor is indicative of acute laryngotracheobronchitis, commonly referred to as croup.


Explanation of other options:

Acute epiglottitis (Option A): Typically features high fever, drooling, and respiratory difficulty, often with neck extension to ease breathing. The child looks acutely ill. Stridor appears late. X-ray shows the thumb sign due to a swollen epiglottis.


Foreign body aspiration (Option C): Generally presents with sudden onset of cough or choking, followed by localized wheeze or asymmetric breath sounds on chest examination.


Laryngomalacia (Option D): A congenital anomaly producing chronic inspiratory stridor, which is low-pitched and worsens during crying or exertion. Diagnosis is confirmed with laryngoscopy showing an omega-shaped epiglottis.


Reference:

  1. https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK441873/
  2. https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK431070/

questions.text: A full-term male newborn is examined immediately after birth due to a visible defect in the abdominal wall, as shown in the provided image. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The image and clinical description are characteristic of bladder exstrophy, a congenital defect in which the bladder is open and exposed on the lower abdomen due to failure of closure of the anterior abdominal wall and cloacal membrane.


Bladder Exstrophy:

  • Pathogenesis:
    • Caused by failure of mesodermal infiltration into the cephalad extension of the cloacal membrane.
    • Severity depends on the extent of this failure.
  • Classic Bladder Exstrophy:
    • Bladder is exposed on the anterior abdominal wall.
    • Bladder mucosa is visible externally.
  • Abdominal Findings:
    • Umbilicus is displaced downward.
    • Pubic rami are widely separated.
    • Rectus abdominis muscles are divided.
  • Genital Anomalies:
    • Males:
      • Complete epispadias with dorsal chordee.
      • Penis is shorter, approximately half the length of normal.
      • Scrotum appears broad, shallow, and slightly separated from the penis.
      • Associated anomalies: Undescended testes, inguinal hernias.
    • Females:
      • Epispadias with widely separated clitoral halves.
      • Labia are widely spaced.
  • Other Physical Findings:
    • Anteriorly displaced anus in both sexes.
    • Possible rectal prolapse.
    • Significant separation of pubic bones.
    • Affected individuals tend to have shorter stature.
  • Complications if Untreated:
    • Complete urinary incontinence.
    • Increased risk of bladder cancer, particularly adenocarcinoma.

Explanation of other options:

Omphalocele (Option A): This congenital condition involves herniation of abdominal contents into the umbilical cord, and these organs are enclosed within a thin, translucent membrane, a key differentiating point.


Gastroschisis (Option B): In this condition, the intestines exit the abdominal cavity through a defect adjacent to the umbilicus and are not covered by any membrane, unlike in the omphalocele.


Patent vitello intestinal duct (Option C): This anomaly arises when the embryonic duct connecting the yolk sac to the midgut remains open, leading to a fistulous tract or small cystic structure near the umbilicus.

questions.text: A 2-year-old child is brought to the emergency department with a history of sudden-onset rapid heart rate. He is alert, playful, and has stable vital signs. The ECG is shown below. What is the most appropriate initial treatment?
questions.solution:
For a child with PSVT who remains hemodynamically stable, adenosine at a dose of 0.1 mg/kg administered intravenously is the preferred initial therapy. It exerts its effect by causing a transient block in AV nodal conduction, often restoring normal sinus rhythm effectively.

Paroxysmal Supraventricular Tachycardia (PSVT):

  • Clinical Presentation:
    • Abrupt onset of a rapid and regular heartbeat
    • Feelings of dizziness or unsteadiness
    • Shortness of breath
    • Chest pressure or discomfort
    • Increased anxiety
    • Tiredness
    • In advanced cases: fainting, low blood pressure, or heart failure symptoms
  • Electrocardiographic Features:
    • Narrow QRS complexes (duration <120 ms) with regular rhythm
    • Shortened R-R intervals
    • Heart rate ranging from 150-250 bpm
    • P waves might be indistinct or merged with T waves
  • Subtypes:
    • AV Nodal Reentrant Tachycardia (AVNRT): Retrograde P waves may present as pseudo R' in V1 or pseudo S waves in inferior leads
    • AV Reentrant Tachycardia (AVRT): Retrograde P waves may follow the QRS complex

      Fig: Typical AVNRT terminated by carotid sinus massage

  • Management:
    • Acute Intervention:
      • First Step: Try vagal maneuvers (e.g., Valsalva, carotid sinus massage)
      • If Ineffective: Administer IV adenosine as first-line drug
        • A pediatric dose of 0.1 mg/kg of adenosine IV is appropriate
        • If ineffective, the dose may be escalated (up to 0.2 mg/kg) (Option B)
        • Standard dosing: 6-12 mg rapid IV push (in adults)
    • Alternatives: Verapamil, diltiazem, beta-blockers
    • For Unstable Patients: Use synchronized cardioversion
  • Long-Term Strategies:
    • Catheter ablation is often curative in recurrent AVNRT or AVRT
    • Medication options: Beta-blockers or calcium channel blockers to prevent recurrence
    • Selected Cases: Class IC or III antiarrhythmics
  • Lifestyle Tips: Avoid common triggers (caffeine, alcohol, emotional stress), ensure regular exercise and proper sleep

Explanation of other options:

Cardioversion (Option A): Reserved for unstable PSVT or drug-refractory cases, not suitable when vitals are stable.

IV Adrenaline (Option D): Not part of PSVT treatment; indicated in cardiac arrest or anaphylaxis.

questions.text: An 18-month-old child is brought to the pediatric clinic with petechiae and purpura. On examination, there is hepatosplenomegaly. Laboratory tests show hemoglobin of 7 g/dL and a total leukocyte count of 50,000/mm³. What is the most appropriate initial pharmacologic management?
questions.solution:
The combination of clinical signs, such as hepatosplenomegaly, anemia, leukocytosis, and bleeding symptoms in a child, is highly indicative of acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL). The recommended initial pharmacologic approach for such a diagnosis commonly includes Vincristine and Prednisolone.


Explanation of other options:

Intravenous immunoglobulin (IVIG) (Option B): Though effective in treating immune thrombocytopenic purpura (ITP), it does not serve as a frontline therapy for ALL.

L-Asparaginase + Prednisolone (Option C): While part of the broader ALL regimen, this pair is generally used in combination with other drugs like Vincristine and is not typically used in isolation as initial therapy.

Daunorubicin + Prednisolone (Option D): This pairing is more frequently seen in the treatment of acute myeloid leukemia (AML) and is not the preferred initial treatment for ALL.

questions.text: A child presents with symptoms including generalized body pain, delayed wound healing, corkscrew-shaped hairs on the arms, and radiographic evidence as shown below. Based on these clinical signs, which of the following micronutrient deficiencies is most likely responsible?
questions.solution:
Vitamin C deficiency (scurvy) impairs collagen synthesis, leading to fragile blood vessels, resulting in bleeding, delayed wound healing, and characteristic features like corkscrew hairs and scorbutic rosary. X-ray findings such as lines of Frenkel further support the diagnosis.


  • A classical radiological sign in scurvy is the presence of white lines of Frenkel, visible on X-rays.
  • Another important sign is the scorbutic rosary, which is a sharp, tender, and angular prominence at the costochondral junction.

Vitamin C:

  • Recommended Daily Allowance (RDA):
    • Infants 0-6 months: 40 mg/day
    • Infants 7-12 months: 50 mg/day
  • Dietary Sources: Citrus fruits and juices, green leafy vegetables, guava, melons, and cauliflower.
  • Common Causes:
    • Diets lacking in fruits and vegetables
    • Use of boiled milk or unfortified formula
  • Early Manifestations:
    • Irritability
    • Loss of appetite
    • Low-grade fever
    • Generalized tenderness, especially in the legs
  • Advanced Symptoms:
    • Hemarthrosis (joint bleeds)
    • Swollen, painful joints
    • Pseudoparalysis due to intense pain
    • Frog-leg posture due to hip and knee flexion
    • Scorbutic rosary: distinct angular swellings of costochondral junctions
  • Treatment:
    • Administration of 100-200 mg/day of vitamin C, orally or parenterally
    • Clinical improvement typically seen within one week
    • Treatment is continued for a duration of 3 months

Explanation of other options:

Zinc deficiency (Option A): Associated with impaired immunity, skin lesions, and delayed growth.

Copper deficiency (Option C): Leads to anemia, low neutrophil counts, and changes in hair and skin pigmentation.

Iron deficiency (Option D): Presents with pallor, lethargy, irritability, and classical signs of iron-deficiency anemia.

questions.text: A teenage girl presents with a history of unintentionally dropping objects from her hands, particularly in the early mornings and during periods of stress such as examinations. There is no associated loss of consciousness. A family member has been diagnosed with epilepsy. EEG reveals epileptic discharges. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The presentation of sudden hand jerks in the morning and during stressful events (e.g., exams) in an adolescent, along with a family history of epilepsy and EEG showing epileptic activity, is characteristic of Juvenile Myoclonic Epilepsy (JME).

Juvenile Myoclonic Epilepsy (JME):

  • Also known as Janz syndrome, it is a type of generalized epilepsy.
  • Onset typically occurs during early adolescence (ages 12-18).
  • Characterized by bilateral myoclonic jerks, especially soon after waking up.
    • Patients may drop objects in the morning due to sudden myoclonic jerks.
  • Generalized tonic-clonic seizures may also be seen, often occurring on awakening.
  • EEG shows generalized polyspike-wave discharges, typically 4-6 Hz.
  • Family history of epilepsy and epileptic EEG patterns support the diagnosis.
  • Triggers include lack of sleep, alcohol intake, and photic stimulation.
  • Treatment Approach:
    • Common antiepileptic drugs used:
      • Sodium valproate
      • Levetiracetam
      • Topiramate
    • Lifelong therapy is usually required due to a high chance of seizure recurrence.
    • Complete remission is rare, hence long-term follow-up is essential.

Explanation of other options:

Atypical absence seizures (Option B): More common in younger children and associated with developmental delays and slow spike-wave patterns on EEG (1-2 Hz), not myoclonic jerks.

Lennox-Gastaut syndrome (Option C): This epilepsy syndrome presents in younger children with multiple seizure types (tonic, atonic, atypical absence) and developmental delay, not myoclonic jerks triggered by awakening or stress.

Centrotemporal spikes (Option D): Typically occurs in children between 3-13 years, often during sleep, with focal facial seizures, not generalized myoclonic jerks.

questions.text: A 2-year-old boy is brought to the pediatric clinic due to delayed developmental milestones and difficulty in breathing through the nose. On examination, he has coarse facial features, a depressed nasal bridge, macroglossia, thick lips, corneal clouding, and hepatosplenomegaly. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical presentation of coarse facies, macroglossia, corneal clouding, hepatosplenomegaly, depressed nasal bridge, and developmental delay strongly suggests Hurler syndrome (MPS I).

Hurler Syndrome:

  • A form of Mucopolysaccharidosis Type I (MPS I).
  • Hurler syndrome is a genetic lysosomal storage disorder resulting from a deficiency of the enzyme α-L-iduronidase.
  • This enzymatic defect leads to the buildup of glycosaminoglycans (GAGs), specifically dermatan sulfate and heparan sulfate, within various tissues and organs.
  • Characteristic Clinical Features:
    • Facial Changes: Broad nasal bridge, coarse features, enlarged tongue, and thick lips.
    • Organ Involvement: Liver and spleen become enlarged due to storage of GAGs.
    • Respiratory Symptoms: Persistent nasal discharge and frequent upper respiratory infections.
    • Eye Involvement: Corneal clouding may reduce visual clarity.
    • Neurological Findings: Developmental delays and cognitive regression.
    • Skeletal Findings (Dysostosis Multiplex): Abnormal bone growth, thickened ribs, and distinctive spinal changes.
    • Cardiac Complications: Valvular heart disease is a common issue and a cause of long-term morbidity.
  • Radiological Signs: Abnormal shapes of vertebrae and long bones.

Explanation of other options:

Beckwith-Wiedemann Syndrome (Option B): Presents with macrosomia, macroglossia, and abdominal wall defects like omphalocele. Risk of tumors like Wilms tumor is increased, but coarse facies and corneal clouding are not features.

Proteus Syndrome (Option C): A rare overgrowth disorder with asymmetric limb/tissue hypertrophy, skin abnormalities, and skeletal deformities. Does not involve GAG accumulation or organomegaly.

Hypothyroidism (Option D): Infants typically present with prolonged jaundice, hypotonia, umbilical hernia, and macroglossia, but coarse facies, corneal clouding, and hepatosplenomegaly are not features, distinguishing it from Hurler syndrome.

questions.text: A child presents with complaints of dark brown urine and reduced urine output for the past 3 days. On examination, he has mild puffiness around the eyes and pedal edema. His blood pressure is elevated at 126/90 mmHg. Urinalysis reveals 2+ protein, >100 RBCs per high power field, and a few granular casts. Blood urea is 56 mg/dL, and creatinine is 0.9 mg/dL. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The child's clinical picture of cola-colored urine, decreased urine output, puffiness, and elevated blood pressure along with laboratory findings of hematuria, moderate proteinuria, and granular casts, is consistent with a nephritic syndrome pattern. Among the choices, PSGN (Poststreptococcal Glomerulonephritis) is the most likely cause.

  • Acute Poststreptococcal Glomerulonephritis (APSGN)
  • Triggered by infections caused by Group A β-hemolytic Streptococcus.
  • Typically follows pharyngitis (after 1-2 weeks) or skin infections like impetigo (after 3-6 weeks).
  • Most frequently affects children between 5 - 12 years of age.
  • Pathophysiology:
    • Caused by immune complex deposition in glomeruli, leading to inflammation and injury.
    • Molecular mimicry between bacterial antigens and kidney tissue may contribute to autoimmunity.
    • This process results in impaired glomerular filtration and leakage of blood/proteins into the urine.
  • Clinical Features:
    • Appears days to weeks after a streptococcal infection.
    • Classic signs of nephritic syndrome:
      • Hematuria
      • Oliguria
      • Edema
      • Elevated blood pressure
    • In some cases, only microscopic hematuria may be seen; in severe cases, acute kidney injury can occur.
  • Diagnostic Findings:
    • Urinalysis:
      • Red blood cells and RBC casts
      • Mild to moderate proteinuria
      • Presence of white cells or granular casts
    • Blood tests:
      • Low serum C3 complement levels in over 90% of cases
      • Normal C4 levels
      • Evidence of recent streptococcal infection:
        • Elevated antistreptolysin-O (ASO) titers (after pharyngitis)
        • High anti-DNase B titers (especially after skin infection)
  • Treatment:
    • Supportive management:
      • Monitor and treat fluid overload and hypertension
      • Restrict sodium and fluid intake
      • Use diuretics (e.g., furosemide) and antihypertensives (e.g., calcium channel blockers, ACE inhibitors)
    • Antibiotics (e.g., penicillin) are used to clear any residual streptococcal infection, though they do not alter the glomerulonephritis course

Explanation of other options:

Nephrolithiasis (Option B): Typically presents with colicky flank pain, gross or microscopic hematuria, and no proteinuria, edema, or hypertension. Urinalysis may show crystals but not granular casts.

Posterior Urethral Valve (Option C): Seen in infant boys, causing urinary obstruction, poor stream, and recurrent UTIs, not nephritic urine findings.

Minimal Change Disease (Option D): Typically causes nephrotic syndrome (massive proteinuria, hypoalbuminemia, generalized edema), not hematuria or hypertension.

questions.text: An 8-year-old male presents with painless hematuria. He also has a history of bilateral sensorineural hearing loss and ocular abnormalities. Light microscopy of the renal biopsy appears normal. His maternal uncle has been diagnosed with chronic kidney disease (CKD Grade 5) and is currently on dialysis. Based on these findings, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The presence of hematuria, sensorineural hearing loss, and ocular anomalies in a child, along with a family history suggestive of X-linked renal disease, strongly indicates Alport syndrome.

Alport Syndrome:

  • Genetics:
    • Mainly X-linked inheritance due to mutations in the COL4A5 gene
    • Autosomal recessive/dominant forms can result from COL4A3 or COL4A4 gene mutations.
  • Pathophysiology:
    • Affects type IV collagen, a critical structural protein in basement membranes, especially the glomerular basement membrane (GBM)
  • Clinical Features:
    • Persistent microscopic hematuria
    • Mild to moderate proteinuria
    • Gradual decline in kidney function
    • Frequently associated with sensorineural hearing loss and ocular findings such as anterior lenticonus, cataracts, or macular flecks
  • Diagnosis:
    • Electron microscopic examination of a kidney biopsy is key for identifying GBM abnormalities including:
      • Thinning
      • Thickening
      • Splitting or a "basket-weave" appearance
    • Genetic testing (e.g., clinical exome sequencing) aids in confirming the specific mutation
    • Family history often supports diagnosis due to hereditary patterns
  • Treatment and Management:
    • ACE inhibitors help reduce proteinuria and slow renal deterioration
    • Blood pressure control is essential
    • Dietary modifications, such as low-sodium intake, may be advised
  • Prognosis:
    • Males with X-linked Alport syndrome commonly progress to end-stage renal disease (ESRD) in adolescence or early adulthood
    • Recessive variants tend to have a faster decline in renal function

Explanation of other options:

Goodpasture syndrome (Option B): Involves anti-GBM antibodies causing pulmonary hemorrhage and rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis. Biopsy would show crescentic glomerulonephritis, which is absent here.

IgA nephropathy (Option C): Typically presents with episodic gross hematuria following upper respiratory infections. Light microscopy shows mesangial proliferation and IgA deposits, unlike the normal light microscopy and GBM changes seen in Alport syndrome.

PSGN (Option D) (Post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis): Typically follows streptococcal infection and presents with edema, hypertension, and cola-colored urine. Biopsy findings include diffuse hypercellularity and neutrophil infiltration, which are not observed here.

Reference: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK470419/#

questions.text: A 3-year-old child presents with a sudden onset of high fever, rapid breathing, inspiratory stridor, difficulty swallowing, and drooling. These symptoms began within the past 4-6 hours. Which of the following treatments should be started in addition to airway stabilization?
questions.solution:
The child presents with acute onset of high fever, stridor, dysphagia, and drooling, which is classic for acute epiglottitis. After ensuring airway security, the next crucial step is initiating intravenous antibiotics such as ceftriaxone or cefotaxime to treat the underlying infection.

Acute Epiglottitis:

  • A severe, rapidly progressive infection of the epiglottis and nearby tissues.
  • Can result in airway obstruction, hypoxia, and respiratory failure if not promptly managed.
  • Common Pathogens
    • Pre-vaccine era: Haemophilus influenzae type b (Hib) was the primary cause.
    • Post-Hib vaccine era: Other bacteria have become more common:
      • Streptococcus pneumoniae (most frequent now)
      • Streptococcus pyogenes
      • Non-typeable Haemophilus influenzae
      • Staphylococcus aureus
    • Widespread use of Hib vaccine has led to a >99% drop in Hib-related cases.
  • Clinical Presentation:
    • Sudden onset with high-grade fever and toxic appearance.
    • Drooling due to inability to swallow saliva.
    • Inspiratory stridor (a late and dangerous sign of airway narrowing).
    • Tripod posture: Sitting forward with neck extended to ease breathing.
    • Rapid breathing, anxiety, and possible cyanosis.
    • If untreated, may progress to loss of consciousness or respiratory arrest.
  • Diagnosis:
    • Laryngoscopy: Shows swollen, cherry-red epiglottis.
    • Lateral neck X-ray: Classic "thumb sign" (enlarged epiglottis).
    • Blood and throat cultures: Collected after securing the airway.
    • CSF analysis: May be done if meningeal signs are present.
  • Treatment
    • Airway management is the top priority:
      • Early intubation or tracheostomy in case of severe obstruction.
    • Empiric IV antibiotics for 7-10 days:
      • Choices: Ceftriaxone, cefepime, or meropenem.
    • Supportive care: Oxygen, IV fluids, and close monitoring in ICU.
  • Prognosis:
    • With prompt treatment, most children recover within a few days.
    • Mortality drops significantly (<1%) with airway protection and antibiotics.

Explanation of other options:

Nebulisation with racemic adrenaline (Option A): Racemic adrenaline is primarily used in croup (laryngotracheobronchitis), not epiglottitis. It provides temporary airway relief in subglottic obstruction, whereas epiglottitis involves supraglottic swelling.

Diphtheria antitoxin (Option C): Diphtheria antitoxin is used to neutralize the toxin in diphtheria, which presents with grayish pseudomembranes in the throat, not a swollen epiglottis with drooling and tripod posture.

Start steroids (Option D): Steroids are used in croup to reduce subglottic inflammation but are not indicated in epiglottitis, which involves supraglottic swelling and requires antibiotics after airway stabilization.

Reference:

  1. https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK441873/
  2. https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK431070/
  3. https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK430960/
  4. https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S1930043321002156

questions.text: Match the following developmental milestones with their corresponding ages:
questions.solution: The correct match is 1-b, 2-a, 3-d, 4-c.

questions.text:
A 2-year-old child is brought to the emergency department with a sudden onset of choking while playing. On examination, breath sounds are diminished over the left lung field. What are the most appropriate steps in the initial management of this child?
1. Bronchoscopy
2. Computed tomography scan
3. ICD insertion
4. Chest x-ray
questions.solution:
The child’s sudden choking episode with reduced breath sounds on one side suggests foreign body aspiration causing lower airway obstruction. The initial management includes a chest X-ray as the first-line investigation to detect signs like unilateral hyperinflation or collapse. If suspicion persists, bronchoscopy is the definitive diagnostic and therapeutic procedure for confirmation and removal of the foreign body.

Lower Airway Foreign Body Aspiration:

  • Epidemiology:
    • A common emergency in young children, especially those under 4 years of age.
    • Most cases occur in toddlers and older infants during play or eating.
  • Frequent Aspirated Items:
    • Food-related: Nuts, seeds, hard candy, chewing gum, bones, pieces of fruits or vegetables.
    • Non-food items: Coins, balloons, small toys, magnets, pen caps, pins, and jewelry.
  • Typical Sites of Lodgement:
    • Most commonly affects the bronchi, followed by the trachea, and then the larynx.
  • Types of Obstruction:
    • Partial Obstruction:
      • Acts as a one-way valve during expiration, leading to localized air trapping or hyperinflation.
      • Clinical signs: Reduced breath sounds, hyperresonance, and diminished vocal fremitus on the affected side.
    • Complete Obstruction:
      • Causes lung collapse (atelectasis) and can eventually result in chronic lung damage like bronchiectasis.
  • Clinical Phases:
    • Initial Phase: Sudden coughing, choking, or gagging during the aspiration event.
    • Asymptomatic Phase: Temporary relief may follow, which can delay diagnosis if the foreign body remains lodged.
    • Complications Phase: Later symptoms may include fever, persistent cough, hemoptysis, pneumonia, or localized lung collapse.
  • Diagnostic Approach:
    • History: A witnessed choking episode is often the most critical clue.
    • Chest X-ray (Option 4): First-line investigation; although many foreign bodies are radiolucent, secondary signs like unilateral hyperinflation or collapse may be seen.
    • Expiratory Films: Helpful in showing air trapping in suspected cases.
    • CT Chest (Option 2): Offers detailed imaging but involves radiation exposure; considered when X-rays are inconclusive.
    • Bronchoscopy (Option 1): Definitive diagnostic and therapeutic tool, especially if suspicion remains despite negative imaging.
  • Management:
    • Rigid Bronchoscopy: Gold standard for both diagnosis and removal of the foreign object.
    • Antibiotic Therapy: May be required if secondary infection is suspected.

Explanation of other options:

ICD insertion (Option 3): Intercostal Drain (ICD) is used for pleural pathologies like pneumothorax, not for airway obstructions.

questions.text: A 4-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department with a 6-day history of high-grade fever. On examination, he has bilateral non-purulent conjunctival injection, erythema of the palms and soles, cervical lymphadenopathy, and the oral findings shown in the image below. A 2D echocardiogram reveals the presence of coronary artery aneurysms. What is the most appropriate first-line treatment for this child?
questions.solution:
The child shows classical features of Kawasaki disease, including prolonged fever, mucocutaneous changes like strawberry tongue, conjunctivitis, extremity changes, and coronary aneurysms. The first-line therapy is IVIG, which significantly reduces the risk of coronary artery complications.

Kawasaki Disease (KD):

  • Predominantly affects children under 5 years.
  • Characterized by systemic vasculitis, primarily involving medium-sized arteries, with a special predilection for coronary arteries.
  • Clinical Presentation:
    • Persistent high-grade fever (≥5 days).
    • Extremity changes: Redness, swelling, and later peeling around nails and fingertips.
    • Mucocutaneous signs:
      • Bilateral, non-purulent conjunctivitis.
      • Dry, cracked lips; strawberry tongue; oropharyngeal redness.
    • Rash: Polymorphic (may be maculopapular, urticarial, or erythema multiforme-like).
    • Lymphadenopathy: Usually unilateral and cervical.
  • Diagnostic Criteria:
    • Fever ≥5 days AND
    • At least 4 out of 5 of the following ("CREAM" mnemonic):
      • C - Conjunctivitis (bilateral, non-exudative)
      • R - Rash (polymorphous, not vesicular)
      • E - Extremity changes (erythema/edema of palms/soles ± peeling)
      • A - Adenopathy (cervical, typically unilateral)
      • M - Mucosal involvement (e.g., strawberry tongue, red lips)

  • Investigations:
    • Elevated inflammatory markers: CRP, ESR
    • Leukocytosis
    • Echocardiography: To assess for coronary artery abnormalities
  • Management:
    • IVIG (Intravenous Immunoglobulin):
      • First-line therapy.
      • Should be given within 10 days of symptom onset to reduce coronary complications.
    • Aspirin:
      • High-dose during acute inflammation.
      • Low-dose continued during convalescence for its antiplatelet effect.
    • For Refractory Cases (IVIG-resistant KD)
      • Repeat IVIG dose.
      • Consider corticosteroids, infliximab, or other immunomodulators (e.g., cyclosporine).

Explanation of other options:

Aspirin (Option A): Administered adjunctively with IVIG in high doses during the acute phase for anti-inflammatory effects, followed by low doses for antiplatelet effects, but not used as monotherapy.

Clopidogrel (Option C): Reserved for more advanced thrombosis or when aspirin is contraindicated.

LMWH (Low Molecular Weight Heparin) (Option D): Indicated in selected patients with large coronary thrombosis, not first-line.

questions.text: A 15-year-old boy is evaluated for short stature. Clinical assessment reveals a disproportionately long lower segment compared to the upper segment, with an upper segment to lower segment (US/LS) ratio of 0.8:1. Which of the following conditions best explains this finding?
questions.solution:
Explanation of correct answer:

Spondyloepiphyseal dysplasia is an inheritable skeletal dysplasia that primarily affects the spine and epiphyses of long bones. It leads to short trunk dwarfism, which means the upper segment is shorter than the lower segment, resulting in a low US/LS ratio.

  • Upper Segment: From the vertex to the pubic symphysis
  • Lower Segment: From the pubic symphysis to the floor
  • US/LS Ratio:
    • At birth: ~1.7
    • By 7 years: ~1.0
    • In adults: ~0.9

Explanation of other options:

Growth hormone deficiency (Option C): Results in proportionate short stature with normal US/LS ratio (approximately 0.9 in adults), unlike the disproportionate long lower segment seen in this case.

questions.text: An 18-month-old child weighing 10 kg is brought to a rural eye screening camp. On examination, the child is found to have a softened and thinned cornea, suggestive of keratomalacia. What is the appropriate therapeutic dose of vitamin A for this child?
questions.solution:
Keratomalacia indicates severe vitamin A deficiency. For children over 12 months, the therapeutic dose is 200,000 IU orally on Day 1, repeated on Day 2, and again after 4 weeks, per WHO guidelines.


Reference:

  1. The eye signs of vitamin A deficiency - PMC
  2. WHO Treatment for Vit A Deficiency
  3. RETINOL = VITAMIN A oral | MSF Medical Guidelines

choices.text: First immunoglobulin, then Hep B vaccine after 1 month

questions.text: A primigravida woman at 37 weeks of gestation presents in active labor with no prior antenatal checkups. Post-delivery, she is found to be positive for Hepatitis B surface antigen (HBsAg). The newborn weighs 2.8 kg and appears stable. What is the most appropriate management for the newborn?
questions.solution:
Explanation of correct answer:

For newborns of HBsAg-positive mothers, administer Hepatitis B vaccine and Hepatitis B immunoglobulin (HBIG) within 12 hours of birth to provide active and passive immunity, preventing perinatal transmission.


Explanation of other options:

Hep B vaccine only (Option A): Insufficient in neonates born to infected mothers; passive immunity is essential.

First immunoglobulin, then Hep B vaccine after 1 month (Option C): Delaying the vaccine until 1 month is inappropriate, as early active immunization is critical to prevent chronic Hepatitis B infection.

Only immunoglobulin (Option D): Passive protection alone is not sufficient without long-term immune stimulation.

Reference:

  1. Vaccination in Elderly
  2. Vaccination in Post Splenectomy patients
  3. RSV, Shingles

questions.text: A child is brought to the emergency department with generalized tonic-clonic seizures that have lasted for more than 5 minutes without regaining consciousness between episodes. After stabilizing the airway, breathing, and circulation, what is the most appropriate first-line pharmacologic intervention?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of continuous generalized tonic-clonic seizures for more than 5 minutes without regaining consciousness indicates status epilepticus. The most appropriate first-line pharmacologic treatment is intravenous lorazepam, due to its rapid onset and sustained anticonvulsant effect.

Status Epilepticus:

  • Medical emergency involving prolonged or repeated seizures without regaining consciousness between episodes.
  • Updated definition:
    • Seizure activity lasting ≥5 minutes, or
    • Two or more seizures occurring without full recovery of consciousness in between.
  • Previous definition: Seizures lasting more than 30 minutes.
  • Timely treatment is essential, as neuronal injury may begin within 5 to 30 minutes of ongoing seizure activity.
  • Stepwise Management of Status Epilepticus:

questions.text: A 4-year-old child is brought to the pediatric clinic with a gradually enlarging abdominal mass noted over the past few weeks. On examination, a firm, non-tender, non-fluctuant, and non-mobile mass measuring approximately 14 cm is palpable in the left flank. The child appears otherwise well, with no fever, hematuria, or weight loss. There are no overlying skin changes or signs of inflammation. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation of correct answer:

The presence of a gradually enlarging, firm, non-tender, non-mobile, and non-fluctuant flank mass in a child, without systemic signs like fever, hematuria, or weight loss, is most consistent with Wilms tumor.


Explanation of other options:

Angiomyolipoma (Option B): A benign renal tumor associated with tuberous sclerosis, rare in children, and typically seen in older females, not presenting as a large mass in young children.

Renal cell carcinoma (Option C): Rare in children under 5, typically affecting older children or adolescents, and often presents with hematuria or pain, unlike the asymptomatic mass in this case.

Neuroblastoma (Option D): Commonly affects children under 5 and can present with an abdominal mass, but it typically originates from the adrenal gland and may cross the midline. It often presents with systemic symptoms such as weight loss, fever, and sometimes paraneoplastic syndromes.

questions.text: A newborn presents shortly after birth with persistent frothing at the mouth and respiratory distress. The symptoms worsen during attempts at feeding. A nasogastric tube was inserted, and a chest X-ray was obtained. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation of correct answer:

The newborn’s presentation of persistent frothing at the mouth, worsening respiratory distress during feeding, and failure to pass a nasogastric tube into the stomach, along with a chest X-ray showing the tube coiled in the upper esophageal pouch, strongly suggests esophageal atresia with tracheo-esophageal fistula (TEF).


Explanation of other options:

Transient tachypnea of newborn (Option A): Presents with mild respiratory distress in term infants within hours of birth, resolving within 72 hours. It lacks feeding-related symptoms like frothing or choking.

Congenital diaphragmatic hernia (Option B): Typically presents with severe respiratory distress soon after birth due to lung compression by herniated abdominal contents. X-ray would show bowel loops in the thoracic cavity, mediastinal shift, and a scaphoid abdomen-not a coiled tube in the upper chest.

Respiratory distress syndrome (Option D): Seen in preterm neonates due to surfactant deficiency. It manifests within hours of birth with grunting, retractions, and cyanosis. Chest X-ray reveals bilateral ground-glass opacities and air bronchograms. NG tube passage would not be impaired.

Reference:

  1. https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK560848/

questions.text: A 5-day-old newborn presents with poor feeding and increased irritability. On examination, the infant is pale, with cool lower limbs. The femoral pulses are weak compared to the brachial pulses, and there is a significant difference in blood pressure between the upper and lower extremities. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The newborn's presentation of poor feeding, increased irritability, pallor, cool lower limbs, radiofemoral delay, and a notable difference in blood pressure between the upper and lower limbs is highly suggestive of Coarctation of the Aorta (CoA).


Coarctation of the Aorta (CoA):

  • Refers to a congenital narrowing of a segment of the aorta, typically located near the insertion point of the ductus arteriosus, but it can occur anywhere from the aortic arch to the bifurcation of the iliac arteries.
  • Clinical Features:
    • Differential Cyanosis
    • Signs of Heart Failure in severe cases
    • Lower Limb Discomfort or Fatigue: Older children may report leg pain or claudication following exertion due to reduced perfusion.
    • Radiofemoral Delay: Noticeable delay and weakening of femoral pulses compared to brachial pulses, often accompanied by a blood pressure discrepancy (higher in the upper limbs than the lower).
    • Murmurs: A systolic murmur (sometimes continuous) can be heard over the back and chest due to the development of collateral circulation.
  • Investigations:
    • Chest X-Ray:
      • Prominent shadow in the upper left mediastinum due to an enlarged left subclavian artery.
      • Rib Notching: Indentation of the inferior margins of the ribs caused by enlarged intercostal collaterals (usually evident after the first decade).
      • Post-stenotic Dilatation: Visible enlargement of the descending aorta beyond the narrowed segment.
    • Other Imaging: Echocardiography with Color Doppler, ECG, CT angiography or MRI
  • Management:
    • Prostaglandin E1 Infusion: Used in neonates to keep the ductus arteriosus open, thereby restoring blood flow to the lower body.
    • Definitive Treatment: Surgical correction

Explanation of other options:

Transposition of Great Arteries (Option A) presents with early central cyanosis due to parallel circulation, but does not cause differential pulses between upper and lower limbs.

Tetralogy of Fallot (Option C) presents with cyanosis due to right-to-left shunting and tet spells, but femoral pulses are normal, and there is no blood pressure discrepancy between upper and lower limbs.

Ebstein anomaly (Option D) is a right-sided heart defect involving the tricuspid valve, often leading to cyanosis or arrhythmias, but it does not impair aortic flow to cause pulse or BP differences.
